                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form>, (AZ, S, M, A, Msb, K,) and <foreign lang="ar">إِلَيْهِ</foreign>, (A,) aor.      
    <form n="infl">       
                     <orth orig="Ba" lang="ar">اَنَسَ</orth>
                  </form>; (Msb, TA;) and <foreign lang="ar">أَنَسَ</foreign>, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) aor.

                     <orth orig="Bi" lang="ar">اَنِسَ</orth>
                  </form> (M, Msb, TA) and      
    <form n="infl">       
                     <orth orig="Bu" lang="ar">اَنُسَ</orth>
                  </form>; (M;) and <foreign lang="ar">أَنُسَ</foreign>, aor.      
    <form n="infl">       
                     <orth orig="Bu" lang="ar">اَنُسَ</orth>
                  </form>; (M, Sgh, K;) inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">أَنَسٌ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">أَنَسَةٌ</foreign>, (S, K,) both of <foreign lang="ar">أَنِسَ</foreign>, (S,) or <foreign lang="ar">إِنَسٌ</foreign>, (AZ, AHát, T, M, Msb,) also of <foreign lang="ar">أَنِسَ</foreign>, (AZ, AHát, Msb, TA,) but this is rare, (T, TA,) and <foreign lang="ar">أُنْسٌ</foreign>, (T, S, M, A, K,) which is the more common, (T, TA,) and is of <foreign lang="ar">أَنَسَ</foreign>, (S,) or <foreign lang="ar">أُنْسٌ</foreign> has a different signification from <foreign lang="ar">إِنْسٌ</foreign> the inf. n. of <foreign lang="ar">أَنِسَ</foreign>, [see <foreign lang="ar">أُنْسٌ</foreign> below,] (AZ, AHát,) or it is a subst. from <foreign lang="ar">أَنِسَ بِهِ</foreign>, (Msb,) and <foreign lang="ar">أُنْسَةٌ</foreign>; (M;) [but this also is probably a subst.;] one says <foreign lang="ar">أُنْسٌ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">أُنْسَةٌ</foreign>, like as one says <foreign lang="ar">بُعْدٌ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">بُعْدَة</foreign>; (Ham p. 768;) <hi rend="ital">He was,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">became, sociable, companionable, conversable, inclined to company or converse, friendly, amicable,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">familiar, with him,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">by means of him,</hi> and <hi rend="ital">to him:</hi> and [<foreign lang="ar">انس به</foreign>] <hi rend="ital">he was,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">became, cheered,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">gladdened, by his company</hi> or <hi rend="ital">converse,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">by his,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">its, presence;</hi> or <hi rend="ital">cheerful, gay,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">gladsome:</hi> the inf. n. signifying the <hi rend="ital">contr. of</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">وَحْشَةٌ</foreign>: (T, S, A, K:) or <hi rend="ital">he was,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">became, at ease,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">tranquil, with him:</hi> (M:) or <hi rend="ital">his heart was,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">became, at ease,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">tranquil, with him; without shrinking,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">aversion:</hi> (Msb:) and <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n1330-1" target="استأنس" n="1" type="5" subtype="FSO" lang="ar" select="n1334"/>بِهِ</foreign>, (S, M, A, Msb,) and <foreign lang="ar">إِلَيْهِ</foreign>, (A,) and <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n1330-2" target="تأنّس" n="2" type="5" subtype="FSO" lang="ar"/>بِهِ</foreign>, signify the same, (S, M, Msb,) i. e., the same as <foreign lang="ar">أَنِسَ</foreign> (M, A, Msb, TA) and <foreign lang="ar">أَنَسَ</foreign> (M, Msb) and <foreign lang="ar">أُنُسَ</foreign>: (M:) <foreign lang="ar">أَنِسَ بِفُلَانٍ</foreign> is likewise explained as signifying <hi rend="ital">he delighted,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">rejoiced, in such a one; he was happy,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pleased, with him:</hi> (IAar, TA:) [and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n1330-3" target="آنسهُ" n="3" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n1331"/></foreign>, a form of frequent occurrence, inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">مُؤَانَسَةٌ</foreign>, which occurs in this art. in the TA, also signifies <hi rend="ital">he was,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">became, sociable,</hi> &amp;c., <hi rend="ital">with him;</hi> like <foreign lang="ar">أَنِسَ بِهِ</foreign> &amp;c.: it is also said in the TA that <foreign lang="ar">أَنِسَ بِهِ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n1330-4" target="آنَسَ" n="4" type="5" subtype="FSO" lang="ar"/>بِهِ</foreign> are syn., meaning, app., like <foreign lang="ar">استأنس</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">تأنّس به</foreign>, and that <foreign lang="ar">آنس</foreign> in this case is therefore of the measure <foreign lang="ar">فَاعَلَ</foreign>; but this admits of some doubt, as it is said immediately after <foreign lang="ar">آنسهُ</foreign> as meaning the contr. of <foreign lang="ar">أَوْحَشَهُ</foreign>:] and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n1330-5" target="استأنس" n="5" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n1334"/></foreign>, (K, TA,) said of a wild animal, (TA,) signifies [<hi rend="ital">he became familiar,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">tame,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">domesticated;</hi> or] <hi rend="ital">his wildness</hi> (<foreign lang="ar">تَوَحُّشُهُ</foreign>) <hi rend="ital">departed:</hi> (K, TA:) you say <foreign lang="ar">إِذَا جَآءَ اللَّيْلُ ٱسْتَأْنَسَ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">كُلُّ وَحْشِىٍّ وَٱسْتَوْحَشَ كُلُّ إِنْسِىٌ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">When the night comes, every wild animal becomes familiar with his kind, and every human being becomes shy of his kind,</hi> i. e., of such thereof as he does not know, when meeting them in the dark]. (A, TA, Msb in art. <foreign lang="ar">وحش</foreign>.)    </entryFree>26:T9e8,<entryFree id="n1331" key="آنسهُ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <itype>4</itype>

                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">آنسة</orth>
                  </form>, (M, K,) inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">إِينَاسٌ</foreign>, (S,) <hi rend="ital">He behaved in a sociable, friendly,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">familiar, manner with him;</hi> [see 1, in two places;] <hi rend="ital">he,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">it, cheered him,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">gladdened him, by his company or converse,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">by his,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">its, presence; he,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">it, solaced,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">consoled, him; contr. of</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">أَوْحَشَهُ</foreign>; (S, * K;) as also   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n1331-1" target="أنّسهُ" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>, (K,) inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">تَأْنِيسٌ</foreign>: (S, K:) or <hi rend="ital">he,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">it, rendered him easy, at ease,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">tranquil;</hi> as also ↓ the latter verb, occurring in the following ex.: <foreign lang="ar">سَمَّاهَا</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">بِٱلْمُؤْنِسَاتِ لِأَنَّهُنَّ يُؤَنِّسْنَهُ بِأَقْرَانِهِ فَيُؤَمِّنَّهُ أَوْيُحَسِّنَّ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">ظَنِّهُ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">He has called them</hi> (referring to weapons) <foreign lang="ar">المؤنسات</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">because they render him at ease with his adversaries, and secure, or cause him to have a good opinion</hi> of his safety, and thus, cheer him, or solace him, by their presence]. (M: [and the like is said in the A.])       <sense type="A" n="2">-A2-</sense>  <hi rend="ital">He perceived it;</hi> syn. of the inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">إِدْرَاكٌ</foreign>. (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  <hi rend="ital">He saw him,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">it,</hi> (S, M, A, * Msb, K,) and <hi rend="ital">looked at him,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">it;</hi> (M, TA;) as also   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n1331-2" target="أنّسهُ" n="2" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>, inf. n.    </entryFree>27:T86d,<entryFree id="n1332" key="تَأْنِيسٌ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">تَأْنِيسٌ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form>; (K;) and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n1332-1" target="استأنسهُ" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>: (M:) or <hi rend="ital">he saw it so that there was no doubt or uncertainty in it:</hi> or <hi rend="ital">he saw it,</hi> meaning a thing by the sight or presence of which he was cheered, gladdened, solaced, or consoled; <foreign lang="ar">إِينَاسٌ</foreign> signifying <foreign lang="ar">إِبْصَارُ مَا</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">يُؤْنَسُ بِهِ</foreign>: (Bd in xx. 9:) or <hi rend="ital">he saw it, not having before known it,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">been acquainted with it.</hi> (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  <hi rend="ital">He heard it;</hi> namely, a sound or voice. (S, K.)          <sense type="b" n="3">-b3-</sense>  <hi rend="ital">He felt it; was sensible of it;</hi> (M, K, TA;) <hi rend="ital">experienced it in himself;</hi> (TA;) namely, [for instance,] fright, or fear. (A, TA.)          <sense type="b" n="4">-b4-</sense>  <hi rend="ital">He knew it:</hi> (S, M, Msb, K:) <hi rend="ital">he was acquainted with it:</hi> (TA:) <hi rend="ital">he had certain knowledge of it; was certain of it.</hi> (M, TA.) You say, <foreign lang="ar">آنَسْتُ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">مِنْهُ رُشْدًا</foreign> (S, A, TA) <hi rend="ital">I knew him to be characterized by</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">رُشْد</foreign>, (S, TA,) i. e., <hi rend="ital">maturity of intel-lect, and rectitude of actions, and good management of affairs.</hi> (TA.) [See Kur iv. 5.] And it is said in a prov., <foreign lang="ar">بَعْدَ ٱطِّلَاعٍ إِينَاسٌ</foreign>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">After appearance</hi> [<hi rend="ital">is knowledge,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">certain knowledge</hi>]. (Fr, TA.)    </entryFree>28:Tc7c,<entryFree id="n1334" key="استأنس" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <itype>10</itype>        
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">استأنس</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form>, and <foreign lang="ar">استأنس بِهِ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">إِلَيْهِ</foreign>: see 1.       <sense type="A" n="2">-A2-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">استأنس</foreign> signifies also <hi rend="ital">He</hi> (a wild animal) <hi rend="ital">became sensible of the presence or nearness of a human being.</hi> (S, K.)       <sense type="A" n="3">-A3-</sense>  <hi rend="ital">He looked;</hi> as in the phrase <foreign lang="ar">اِذْهَبْ فَٱسْتَأْنِسْ هَلْ تَرَى أَحَدًا</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">Go thou and look if thou see any one</hi>]: (Fr, TA:) <hi rend="ital">he considered,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">examined, endeavouring to obtain a clear knowledge of a thing;</hi> (K, TA;) <hi rend="ital">and looked aside,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">about, to ascertain if he could see any one:</hi> (TA:) <hi rend="ital">he sought,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">asked for, knowledge,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">information; he inquired:</hi> (M, TA:) and hence, (Bd in xxiv. 27,) <hi rend="ital">he asked permission.</hi> (Fr, Zj, K, TA, and Bd ubi suprà.) It is said in the Kur [xxiv. 27], <foreign lang="ar">لَا تَدْخُلُوا بُيُوتًا غَيْرَ بُيُوتِكُمْ حَتَّي تَسْتَأْنِسُوا</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">وَتُسَلِّمُوا</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">Enter ye not houses other than your own houses</hi>] <hi rend="ital">until ye inquire</hi> whether its inhabitants desire that ye should enter or not; [<hi rend="ital">and salute:</hi>] (M:) or (which is essentially the same, M) <hi rend="ital">until ye ask permission:</hi> (Fr, Zj, M, TA:) but Fr says that the sentence presents an inversion, and that the meaning is, <hi rend="ital">until ye salute, and ask if ye shall enter or not:</hi> (TA:) I'Ab says that <foreign lang="ar">تَستأنسوا</foreign> is a mistranscription; and he and Ubeí and Ibn-Mes'ood read <foreign lang="ar">تَسْتَأْذِنُوا</foreign>, which signifies the same: (Az, TA:) [it is said that] <foreign lang="ar">استأنس</foreign> also signifies <hi rend="ital">he made a reiterated hemming, like a slight coughing;</hi> [as a man does to notify his nearness;] syn. <foreign lang="ar">تَنَحْنَحَ</foreign>: and so some explain it in the text of the Kur quoted above. (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">استأنس لَهُ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">He listened to,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">endeavoured</hi> or <hi rend="ital">sought to hear, him,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">it;</hi> as also   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n1334-1" target="تأنّس" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>. (A.) [See the Kur xxxiii. 53.]       <sense type="A" n="4">-A4-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">استأنسهُ</foreign>: see 4.    </entryFree>29:T1061,<entryFree id="n1335" key="أُنْسٌ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">أُنْسٌ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form> 
                  <hi rend="ital">Sociableness; companionableness; conversableness; inclination to company</hi> or <hi rend="ital">converse; friendliness; amicableness; socialness; familiarity: cheerfulness; gayness; gladsomeness: contr. of</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">وَحْشَةٌ</foreign>: (T, S, A, K:) <hi rend="ital">joy; gladness; happiness:</hi> (Har p. 652:) or <hi rend="ital">ease,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">tranquillity:</hi> (M:) or <hi rend="ital">ease,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">tranquillity, of heart, and freedom from shrinking,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">from aversion:</hi> (Msb:) an inf. n. of 1, (S, M,) as are also   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n1335-1" target="أَنَسٌ" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n1338"/></foreign> and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n1335-2" target="أَنَسَةٌ" n="2" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n1339"/></foreign> (S, K) and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n1335-3" target="إِنْسٌ" n="3" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n1336"/></foreign>, (M,) but this is rare as signifying the contr. of <foreign lang="ar">وَحْشَةٌ</foreign>: (T, TA:) or   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n1335-4" target="إِنْسٌ" n="4" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n1336"/></foreign> is the inf. n. of <foreign lang="ar">أَنِسَ بِهِ</foreign>; but <foreign lang="ar">أُنُسٌ</foreign> is not: (AZ, AHát, Msb, TA:) this latter is a subst. from that verb [signifying as explained above]: (Msb:) or only signifying <hi rend="ital">converse, and companionship,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">familiarity, with women;</hi> (AZ, AHát, TA;) or <hi rend="ital">amatory conversation and conduct;</hi> or the <hi rend="ital">talk of young men and young women:</hi> (Fr, TA:) [but of all the forms above, <foreign lang="ar">أُنْسٌ</foreign> is that which is most commonly used, at least in post-classical works, as signifying the contr. of <foreign lang="ar">وَحْشَةٌ</foreign>.]          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  [Also <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">Delight,</hi> as meaning <hi rend="ital">a cause of delight,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">thing that gives delight.</hi>] A poet says, <quote>
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">يَا سَاكِنِى مَكَّةَ لَا زِلْتُمُ</foreign>
                     </L> 
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">أُنْسًا لَنَا إِنِّىَ لَمْ أَنْسَكُمْ</foreign>
                     </L> 
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">مَا فِيكُمُ عَيْبٌ سِوَى قَوْلِكُمْ</foreign>
                     </L> 
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">عِنْدَ اللِّقَا أَوْحَشَنَا أُنْسُكُمْ</foreign>
                     </L> 
                  </quote> [<hi rend="ital">O inhabitants of Mekkeh, may ye not cease to be a delight to us: verily I have not forgotten you: there is in you no fault beside your saying, at meeting, Your sociableness,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">companiableness,</hi> &amp;c., <hi rend="ital">has made us feel lonely and sad;</hi> meaning, in your absence]. (TA in art. <foreign lang="ar">وحش</foreign>.) [See <foreign lang="ar">أَوْحَشَ</foreign>. But this signification, though allowable as tropical, is perhaps post-classical.]          <sense type="b" n="3">-b3-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">اِبْنُ أُنْس</foreign>: and <foreign lang="ar">فُلَانٌ ٱبْنُ أُنْسِ فُلَانٍ</foreign>: and <foreign lang="ar">كَيْفَ ٱبْنُ أُنْسِكَ</foreign>: and <foreign lang="ar">كَيْفَ تَرَى ٱبْنَ أُنْسِكَ</foreign>: see <foreign lang="ar">إِنْسٌ</foreign>.    </entryFree>2a:T2cff,<entryFree id="n1336" key="إِنْسٌ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">إِنْسٌ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">أنس</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">أنسى</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">إنس</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">انس</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ناس</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">نسي</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">آنس</orth>
                  </form>: see <foreign lang="ar">أُنْسٌ</foreign>, in two places.       <sense type="A" n="2">-A2-</sense>  <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">A chosen, select, particular,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">special, friend</hi> or <hi rend="ital">companion;</hi> (S, K;) as also <foreign lang="ar">اِبْنُ إِنْسٍ</foreign> (S, K,) or   
      <foreign lang="ar">اِبْنُ <ref cref="n1336-1" target="أُنْسٍ" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>. (So in a copy of the A.) You say, <foreign lang="ar">هٰذَا إِنْسِى</foreign>; (S;) and <foreign lang="ar">إِنْسُكَ</foreign>, and <foreign lang="ar">ٱبْنُ إِنْسِكَ</foreign>; (K;) <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">This is my chosen,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">particular, friend;</hi> (S;) and <hi rend="ital">thy chosen,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">particular, friend.</hi> (K.) And <foreign lang="ar">فُلَانٌ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">ٱبْنُ إِنْسِ فُلَانٍ</foreign> (S,) or <foreign lang="ar">ابن <ref cref="n1336-2" target="أُنْسِ" n="2" type="5" subtype="FSO" lang="ar"/>فلان</foreign> (A,) <pb n="114"/> <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">Such a one is the chosen,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">particular, friend of such a one.</hi> (S, A.) One also says, <foreign lang="ar">كَيْفَ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">ٱبْنُ إِنْسِكَ</foreign> and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n1336-3" target="أُنْسِكَ" n="3" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>, (S, M,) or <foreign lang="ar">كَيْفَ تَرَي ٱبْنَ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">إِنْسِكَ</foreign> (AZ, Fr, A) and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n1336-4" target="أُنْسِكَ" n="4" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>, (A,) meaning himself, (AZ, Fr, S, S TA,) i. e., <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">How dost thou regard me in my companionship with thee?</hi> (S:) or the meaning is, <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">how dost thou find thyself?</hi> (A:) or <hi rend="ital">how is thyself?</hi> (M, TA.)       <sense type="A" n="3">-A3-</sense>  <hi rend="ital">Mankind;</hi> (S, M, A, K;) the <hi rend="ital">opposite of</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">جِنٌّ</foreign>; (Msb;) as also   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n1336-5" target="أَنَسٌ" n="5" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n1338"/></foreign>, (Akh, S, TA,) and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n1336-6" target="إِنْسَانٌ" n="6" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n1344"/></foreign>; (A, K;) the last being a gen. n., (Msb,) but applied to the male (S, * Msb) and female, (S, Msb, K,) and sing. and pl.: (Msb:) one is [also] termed   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n1336-7" target="إِنْسِىٌّ" n="7" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign> and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n1336-8" target="أَنَسِىٌّ" n="8" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>; (S, K;) the former of which is a rel. n. from <foreign lang="ar">إِنْسٌ</foreign>; (M;) [and the latter, from <foreign lang="ar">أَنَسٌ</foreign>: the fem. of each is with <foreign lang="ar">ة</foreign>:] the vulgar apply to a woman, instead of   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n1336-9" target="إِنْسَانٌ" n="9" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n1344"/></foreign>, [which is the more approved,]   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n1336-10" target="إِنْسَانَةٌ" n="10" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>: (S, K:) this latter [accord. to some] should not be used: (S:) but it is correct, though rare: it is said in the K to occur in poetry, but supposed to be post-classical: it occurs, however, in classical poetry, and has been transmitted by several authors: (MF:) the pl. (of <foreign lang="ar">إِنْسٌ</foreign>, M, TA) is <foreign lang="ar">آنَاسٌ</foreign>; (M, K, TA;) and (of the same, K in art. <foreign lang="ar">نوس</foreign>, or of   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n1336-11" target="إِنْسَانٌ" n="11" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n1344"/></foreign>, M) <foreign lang="ar">أُنَاسٌ</foreign>, (M, K ubi suprà,) with which <foreign lang="ar">نَاسٌ</foreign> is syn., (S, M, Msb, K,) being a contraction thereof; (Sb, S, M, Msb;) and (of   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n1336-12" target="إِنْسِىٌّ" n="12" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>, S, M, or   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n1336-13" target="أَنَسِىٌّ" n="13" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>, S, or of   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n1336-14" target="إِنْسَانٌ" n="14" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n1344"/></foreign>, Lh, S, M, Msb) <foreign lang="ar">أَنَاسِىٌّ</foreign>, (Lh, S, M, Msb, K,) like as <foreign lang="ar">كَرَاسِىُّ</foreign> is pl. of <foreign lang="ar">كُرْسِىٌّ</foreign>, or like as <foreign lang="ar">سَرَاحينُ</foreign> is pl. of <foreign lang="ar">سِرحَانٌ</foreign>, but <foreign lang="ar">ى</foreign> being substituted for <foreign lang="ar">ن</foreign>, (M, TA,) after the same manner as they say <foreign lang="ar">أَرَانٍ</foreign> for <foreign lang="ar">أَرَانِبُ</foreign>; (Fr, TA;) and <foreign lang="ar">أَنَاسٍ</foreign>, (Lh, M,) in the accus. case <foreign lang="ar">أَنَاسِىَ</foreign>, as the word is read in the Kur xxv. 51, by Ks, (TA,) and by Yahyà Ibn-El-Hárith, (K, TA,) dropping the <foreign lang="ar">ى</foreign> between the second and last radical letters, [for, with some others, it seems, they held the word to be derived from the root <foreign lang="ar">نسى</foreign>,] (TA,) and <foreign lang="ar">أَنَاسِيَةٌ</foreign>, (S, M, K,) in which the <foreign lang="ar">ة</foreign> is a substitute for one of the two yás in <foreign lang="ar">أَنَاسِىُّ</foreign>, a pl. of <foreign lang="ar">إِنْسَانٌ</foreign>; or, accord. to Mbr, <foreign lang="ar">أَنَاسِيَةٌ</foreign> is pl. of <foreign lang="ar">إِنْسِىٌّ</foreign>, [in the TA, of <foreign lang="ar">إِنْسِيَّةٌ</foreign>, which I regard as a mistranscription,] and is like <foreign lang="ar">زَنَادَقَةٌ</foreign> for <foreign lang="ar">زَنَادِيقُ</foreign>, and <foreign lang="ar">فَرَازِتَةٌ</foreign> for <foreign lang="ar">فَرَازِينُ</foreign>; (M, TA;) and you say also <foreign lang="ar">إِنْسَيُّونَ</foreign>. (TA.) <foreign lang="ar">نَاسٌ</foreign> is masc., as in the Kur ii. 19, &amp;c.; and sometimes fem., as meaning <hi rend="ital">A tribe,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">a body of men,</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">قَبِيلَةٌ</foreign>, or <foreign lang="ar">طَائِفَةٌ</foreign>; as in the phrase, mentioned by Th, <foreign lang="ar">جَآءَتَْكَ النَّاسُ</foreign>, meaning, <hi rend="ital">The tribe,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">portion of people</hi> (<foreign lang="ar">قِطْعَة</foreign>), <hi rend="ital">came to thee.</hi> (M, TA.)   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n1336-15" target="بَنُوالإِنْسَانِ" n="15" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign> means <hi rend="ital">The sons of Adam.</hi> (M.) And <foreign lang="ar">النَّاسُ النَّاسُ</foreign>, an expression mentioned by Sb, means, <hi rend="ital">Men in every place and in every state are men:</hi> a poet says, <quote>
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">بِلَادٌ بَهَا كُنَّا وَكُنَّا نُحِبُّهَا</foreign>
                     </L> 
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">إِذِ النَّاسُ نَاسٌ وَالبِلَادُ بِلَادُ</foreign>
                     </L> 
                  </quote> meaning [<hi rend="ital">A country in which we were, and which we used to love,] since the men were ingenuous men, and the country was a fruitful country.</hi> (M.) The following trad., <foreign lang="ar">لَوْ أَطَاعَ ٱللّٰهُ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">النَّاسَ فِى النَّاسِ لَمْ يَكُنْ نَاسٌ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">If God complied with the prayer of men with respect to men there would be no men,</hi> is said to mean, that men love to have male children born to them, and not females, and if there were no females, or if the females were not, men would cease to be. (TA.) It is related that a party of the jinn, or genii, came to a company of men, and asked permission to go in to them, whereupon the latter said to them, Who are ye? and they answered, <foreign lang="ar">نَاسٌ مِنَ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">الجنِّ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">A people of the jinn</hi>], making their answer to accord. with common usage; for it is customary for men, when it is said to them, Who are ye? to answer, <foreign lang="ar">نَاسٌ مِنْ بَنِى فُلَانٍ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">Men of the sons of such a one</hi>]. (IJ, M, L: but in the L, for <foreign lang="ar">ناس</foreign>, in both instances, we find <foreign lang="ar">أُنَاسٌ</foreign>.) [See also <foreign lang="ar">نَاسٌ</foreign> in art. <foreign lang="ar">نوس</foreign>.] Respecting the derivation of   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n1336-16" target="إِنْسَانٌ" n="16" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n1344"/></foreign>, authors differ, though they agree that the final <foreign lang="ar">ن</foreign> is augmentative: the Basrees say that it is from <foreign lang="ar">الإِنْسُ</foreign>; (Msb;) and its measure is <foreign lang="ar">فِعْلَانٌ</foreign>; (S, Msb;) but an addition, of <foreign lang="ar">ى</foreign>, is made in its dim., [which is <foreign lang="ar">أُنَيْسِيَانٌ</foreign>,] like as an addition is made in <foreign lang="ar">رُوَيْجِلٌ</foreign>, the dim. of <foreign lang="ar">رَجُلٌ</foreign>: (S:) [but it should be observed that <foreign lang="ar">رُوَيْجِلٌ</foreign> is more probably the dim. of <foreign lang="ar">رَاجِلٌ</foreign>:] some say that it is from <foreign lang="ar">إِينَاسٌ</foreign>, signifying “perception,” or “sight,” and “knowledge,” and “sensation;” because man uses these faculties: (TA:) and Mohammad Ibn-'Arafeh El-Wásitee says that men are called <foreign lang="ar">إِنسِيُّونِ</foreign> because they are seen (<foreign lang="ar">يُؤْنَسُونَ</foreign>, i. e.    </entryFree>2b:Tb64,<entryFree id="n1337" key="يُرَوْنَ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">يُرَوْنَ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">رأى</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ورى</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">يرون</orth>
                  </form>), and that the jinn are called <foreign lang="ar">جِنّ</foreign> because they are [ordinarily] concealed (<foreign lang="ar">مُجْتَنُّونَ</foreign>, i. e. <foreign lang="ar">مُتَوَارُونَ</foreign>,) from the sight of men: (TA:) [it is said in the B, as cited in the TA, that the form <foreign lang="ar">أَنِسَان</foreign> is also used for <foreign lang="ar">إِنْسَانٌ</foreign>; as though it were a dual, meaning “a double associate,” i. e., an associate with the jinn and with his own kind; for it is added, <foreign lang="ar">أَنِسَ بِٱلآْجِنِّ وَأَنِسَ بِٱلآْخَلْقِ</foreign>:] some derive the word from <foreign lang="ar">النَّوْسُ</foreign>, signifying “motion:” (TA:) some (namely, the Koofees, Msb) say that it is originally <foreign lang="ar">إِنسِيَانٌ</foreign>, (S, Msb, TA,) of the measure <foreign lang="ar">إِفْعِلَانٌ</foreign>, (S, Msb,) from <foreign lang="ar">النِّسْيَانُ</foreign> [“forgetfulness”], (Msb,) and contracted to make it more easy of pronunciation, because of its being so often used; (S;) but it is restored to its original in forming the dim., (S, Msb,) which is <foreign lang="ar">أُنَيْسِيَانٌ</foreign>: (Msb, TA:) this form of the dim., they say, shows the original form of the word which is its source; (TA;) and they adduce as an indication of its derivation the saying of I'Ab, <foreign lang="ar">إِنَّمَا سُمِّيَ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">إِنْسَانًا لِأَنَّهُ عُهِدَ إِلَيْهِ فَنَسِىَ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">He</hi> (meaning the first man) <hi rend="ital">was only named</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">انسان</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">because he was commanded and he forgot</hi>]: (S, TA:) [in like manner,] it is said that <foreign lang="ar">النَّاسُ</foreign> is originally <foreign lang="ar">النَّاسِى</foreign>; the former of these, accord. to one reading, and the latter accord. to another, occurs in the Kur ii. 195; the latter referring to Adam, and to the words of the Kur in xx. 114: (TA:) but Az holds that <foreign lang="ar">إِنْسِيَانٌ</foreign> is of the measure <foreign lang="ar">فِعْلِيَانٌ</foreign>, from <foreign lang="ar">الإِنْسُ</foreign>, and similar to <foreign lang="ar">خِرْصِيَانٌ</foreign>. (L, TA. *)    </entryFree>2c:T78d,<entryFree id="n1338" key="أَنَسٌ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">أَنَسٌ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form> 
                  <hi rend="ital">i. q.</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">أُنْسٌ</foreign>, q. v. (S, K.)       <sense type="A" n="2">-A2-</sense>  Also <hi rend="ital">i. q.</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">إِنْسٌ</foreign>, q. v. (Akh, S, TA.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  Also <hi rend="ital">A numerous company of men;</hi> (K, * TA;) <hi rend="ital">many men.</hi> (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="3">-b3-</sense>  <hi rend="ital">A tribe</hi> (<foreign lang="ar">حَىُّ</foreign>) <hi rend="ital">staying, residing, dwelling,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">abiding:</hi> (S, K:) the <hi rend="ital">people of a place of alighting or abode:</hi> (M, TA: [but in the latter, in one place, said to be <foreign lang="ar">إِنْسٌ</foreign>, with kesr; though a verse cited in both, as an ex., shows it to be <foreign lang="ar">أَنَسٌ</foreign>:]) the <hi rend="ital">inhabitants of a house:</hi> (AA, TA:) pl. (of the word in the first sense, of these three, TA, and in the second, M, TA) <foreign lang="ar">آنَاسٌ</foreign>. (M, TA.)          <sense type="b" n="4">-b4-</sense>  <hi rend="ital">One with whom a person is sociable.</hi> (Ham p. 136.) You say also, <foreign lang="ar">هُمْ أَنَسُ فُلَانٍ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">They are they with whom such a one is sociable</hi> (<foreign lang="ar">اَلَّذِينَ يَسْتَأْنِسُ إِلَيْهِمْ</foreign>). (Lh, M.) And <foreign lang="ar">هُوَ أَنَسُ فُلَانٍ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">He is much accustomed to the serving of him.</hi> (Har p. 472.)    </entryFree>2d:Tc9b,<entryFree id="n1340" key="إِنْسِىُّ" type="main">

                  <hi rend="ital">Of,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to, mankind; human;</hi> [as also   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n1340-1" target="أَنَسِىٌّ" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>, and

See <foreign lang="ar">إِنْسٌ</foreign>, in two places.          <sense type="b" n="3">-b3-</sense>  [<hi rend="ital">Domestic, as opposed to wild.</hi> Ex.] <foreign lang="ar">حُمُرٌ إِنْسِيَّةٌ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">Domestic asses; asses that are accustomed to the houses:</hi> commonly known as written with kesr to the <foreign lang="ar">أُنْسِيَّةٌ</foreign>: but in the book of Aboo-Moosà is an indication of its being with damm to the <foreign lang="ar">ء</foreign> [<foreign lang="ar">أَنَسِيَّةٌ</foreign>]: and as some relate a trad. in which it occurs, <foreign lang="ar">أَنَسِيَّةٌ</foreign>, which is said to be of no account. (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="4">-b4-</sense>  The <hi rend="ital">left</hi> side (AZ, S, M, Msb, K) of an animal, (Msb,) or of a beast and of a man, (M,) or of anything: (AZ, S, K:) or the <hi rend="ital">right</hi> side: (As, S:) [but the latter seems to be a mistake:] Az says that Lth has well explained this term and its contrary <foreign lang="ar">وَحْشِىٌّ</foreign>, saying that the latter is the right side of every beast; and the former, the <hi rend="ital">left</hi> side; agreeably with those of the first authority in sound learning; and [that] it is related of El-Mufaddal and As and AO, that all of them asserted the latter to be, of every animal except man, [the “far” side, or “off” side,] the side on which it is not milked nor mounted; and the former, [the <hi rend="ital">near</hi> side,] the side <hi rend="ital">on which the rider mounts and the milker milks:</hi> (TA in art.    </entryFree>2e:T697,<entryFree id="n1341" key="وحش" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">وحش</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form>:) [and the like is said, as a citation from Az, in the Msb in art. <foreign lang="ar">وحش</foreign>: but after this, in my copy of the Msb, there seems to be an omission; for it is immediately added, “But Az says, This is not correct in my opinion:”] it is said that everything that is frightened declines to its right side; for the beast is approached to be mounted and milked on the left side, and, fearing thereat, runs away from the place of fear, which is the left side, to the place of safety, which is the right side: (S, * IAmb in Msb; both in art. <foreign lang="ar">وحش</foreign>:) [accordingly,] Er-Rá'ee describes a beast as declining to the side termed <foreign lang="ar">الوحشى</foreign> because frightened on the left side: (S and Msb in art. <foreign lang="ar">وحش</foreign>:) and 'Antarah alludes to one's shrinking with the side so termed from the whip, [which he likens to a cat,] because the whip of the rider is in his right hand: (S in art. <foreign lang="ar">وحش</foreign>:) but Abu-l-'Abbás says that people differ respecting these two terms when relating to a man: that, accord. to some, they mean the same in this case as in the cases of horses <pb n="115"/> and other beasts of carriage, and of camels: but some say, that in the case of a man, the latter term means the part next the shoulder-blade; and the former, the <hi rend="ital">part next the arm-pit.</hi> (TA in art.    </entryFree>2f:T41c,<entryFree id="n1342" key="وحش" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">وحش</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form>.) Of every double member of a man, as the upper half of each arm, and the two fore arms, and the two feet, it means <hi rend="ital">That</hi> [side] <hi rend="ital">which is towards the man;</hi> and <foreign lang="ar">وحشىّ</foreign>, that which turns away from him: (As, S:) or, of the foot, the former means <hi rend="ital">that</hi> [side] <hi rend="ital">which is towards the other foot;</hi> [i. e., the <hi rend="ital">inner</hi> side;] and the latter, the contrary of the former.                   <hi rend="ital">i. q.</hi>   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n1348-1" target="مُؤَانِسٌ" n="1" type="1" subtype="SO" lang="ar" select="n1354"/></foreign> [generally used as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant, meaning, <hi rend="ital">A sociable, companionable, conversable, friendly,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">familiar, person; a cheerful companion</hi>]: (S, K:) <hi rend="ital">one with whom one is sociable, companionable, conversable, friendly, familiar,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">cheerful:</hi> (K:) <hi rend="ital">a person,</hi> (A,) or <hi rend="ital">anything,</hi> (S,) <hi rend="ital">by whose company,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">converse,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">presence, one is cheered, gladdened, solaced,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">consoled.</hi> (S, A.) You say, <foreign lang="ar">مَا بِالدَّارِ أنِيسْ</foreign> (or, as in some copies of the K, <foreign lang="ar">مِنْ أَنِيسٍ</foreign>,) <hi rend="ital">There is not in the house any one by whose company,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">converse,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">presence, one is cheered, gladdened, solaced,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">consoled:</hi> (A:) or <hi rend="ital">there is not in the house any one.</hi> (S, M, K.)       <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n1348-2" target="مَأْنُوسَةُ" n="2" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>, [imperfectly decl., being a proper name and of the fem. gender,] (M,) and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n1348-3" target="المَأْنُوسَةُ" n="3" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>, (M, K,) of which [says ISd] I know no verb: (M:) because, when a man sees it in the night, he becomes cheerful and tranquil thereat, even if it be in a desert land.                   <hi rend="ital">A girl of cheerful mind,</hi> (Lth, A, K, TA,) <hi rend="ital">whose nearness,</hi> and <hi rend="ital">conversation,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">discourse, thou lovest,</hi> (Lth, TA,) or <hi rend="ital">whose conversation,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">discourse, and nearness, are loved:</hi> (A:) or <hi rend="ital">a girl of pleasant conversation</hi> or <hi rend="ital">discourse;</hi> as also

(M, TA.) [See also <foreign lang="ar">أَنِيسٌ</foreign>.]    </entryFree>33:T688,<entryFree id="n1352" key="مُؤْنِس" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">مُؤْنِس</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form> <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  A name which the Arabs, (S, M,) and the ancients, (M,) used to give to <hi rend="ital">Thursday;</hi> (S, M;) because on that day they used to incline to places of pleasure; and 'Alee is related to have said that God created <hi rend="ital">Paradise</hi> on Thursday, and named it thus. (M, TA.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">المُؤْنِسَاتُ</foreign> <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">Weapons:</hi> (M, A:) or <hi rend="ital">all weapons:</hi> (K:) or <hi rend="ital">the spear and the</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">مِغْفَر</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">and the</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">تِجْغَاف</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">and the</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">تَسْبِغَة</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">and the</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">تُرْس</foreign> (Fr, K) <hi rend="ital">and the sword and the helmet:</hi> (IKtt, TA:) so called because they render their possessor at ease with his adversaries, and secure, or cause him to have a good opinion [of his safety, and thus, cheer him, or solace him, by their presence: see 4]. (M, A. *)          <sense type="b" n="3">-b3-</sense>  See also <foreign lang="ar">بَابُونَجٌ</foreign>.
